Basic structure art repositories

There are two art repositories that will be both used but slightly different. I'll first explain the common parts. This is the base directory structure.

  • 2D art
    • Animals
    • Buildings
    • Characters
    • Clothes
    • Concepts
    • Environment
    • GUI
    • Others
    • Props
    • Tests
    • Vehicles
  • 3D Art
    • Animals
    • Buildings
    • Characters
    • Clothes
    • Concepts
    • Environment
    • Others
    • Props
    • Tests
    • Vehicles
  • Documents
    • Graphics
    • Game design
    • Others
  • Audio
    • Ambient
    • Concepts
    • Music
    • Others
    • SFX
    • Tests
    • Voices

This structure is fairly simple and logical the actual structure will be the same with the exception that everything is lowercase and spaces are replaced by underscores (_).

Within these directories one can define their own structure but keep in mind to keep it clean and logical. Here is an example for what can be done with the "props" directory.

  • Props
    • Weapons
    • Shields
    • Armors
    • Potions
    • Artifacts
    • Others

Note that the base structure is excluded in this example but should not be excluded in the repository

Working Art

Within the structural directories there is a strict standard way how we store our material.

Here is the primary outline of how it looks (taking props again as example):

  • Props
    • Weapons
    • Shields
    • Armors
    • Potions
    • Artifacts
      • Holy mustang
        • Source
        • Resources
        • Docs
    • Others

Note that the base structure is excluded in this example but should not be excluded in the repository

Lets explain what it all is. The directory "Holy mustang" describes the name of the material that can be found there. If you can't think of a good name or it is more or less impossible to give it a name then use a descriptive name with optionally a 2 digit number like "Bottle 23". Note that here the rule that spaces are transformed into underscores and everything is lowercase applies.

In the "Holy mustang" directory we found three directories that are required for each and every directory. These are the directories "Source", "Resources" and "Docs". Below you will find an explanation of what you have to put where.

Sources

This directory will contain the source files. The source files are the files that are used to create the material. For example for maya this is *.mb or *.ma, for 3dsmax this is *.max and for Blender this is *.blend.

No exported files or textures or temporary files or whatever else that is not a source file should not be put in there.

Resources

This folder is where you put all your resource files. For art this includes textures, source images for the textures, audio files used and other resources. You should if its needed include the author of the resources. This is however done in the "Docs" directory.

Docs

This directory contains copyright and left notices about each and every file for which it is required. There should also be a file named info.txt that describes what the material should be and optionally how it was created and a todo list if necessary.

Additional notes

If you need to use a material that already is in the repository then just use it but don't put it again in the repository creating double files. Instead of doing that you make a file called uses.txt which lists what resources where used and where they can be found.

Exported Art

Exported art is handled a bit differently. Exported art same scheme as working art with the difference that the subdirectories "Source", "Resources" and "Docs" are not used. All the used textures and exported Crystal Space Library files go directly in the "named" directory.

This will look something like this:

  • Artifacts
    • Holy mustang
      • Holy mustang.xml
      • mustangclean.png
      • mustangdirty.png
  • Others

Note that the base structure is excluded in this example but should not be excluded in the repository

Repositories

Usage

With all these things in the repository it can be quite a hazard to checkout the full repository. But you don't have to do a full checkout. SVN Allows you to checkout each and every directory you wish. With this structure its even simpler. Lets say you want to checkout the Holy mustang source from the working repository ... It is very simple with the command line client: 

 svn co https://cyanox.nl/ptart/3d_art/props/artifacts/holy_mustang/

this will checkout the directories "Source", "Resources" and "Docs" for the Holy mustang so you can work on that alone without checking out all the other stuff that will most likely become quite large.

Tips and notes

  • Using Subversion
  • Always update todo lists, uses.txt and info.txt when needed.
  • If you think a new or extra category or sub category is needed first discuss this before applying
